page.title: 11THE GLEN
page.content: {The Glen}is the local name given to the valley in the West of Port Glasgow. It runs about 1.5 miles from the moorland above the town down to the Clyde. A shallow burn runs down the Glen and there are a few houses on either side of it. A variety of trees and bushes grow in the Glen above the town - hazel, rowan, hawthorn, lime, sycamore, oak and rhodedendron. Plants such as vetch, wild garlic, foxglove, red campion and clover also grow here. Rooks, thrushes, magpies, blackbirds and sparrows all nest in the Glen. At ground level the Glen provides mice, hedgehogs, moles, foxes and squirrels with a natural habitat. The burn too helps sustain life - caddis flies, freshwater shrimps, diving beetles and voles.
